newsitem.title: USA: Alaska Air sees unit's results stabilizing in Q3.
newsitem.headline: Alaska Air sees unit's results stabilizing in Q3.

text.p: Alaska Air Group Inc said Monday it expects the year-over-year results of its unit, Horizon Air Industries Inc, to begin to stabilize in the third quarter and become positive as its fleet transition is completed.
"Horizon is continuing to experience costs associated with its fleet transition," said John Kelly, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Alaska Air.
Horizon posted a pretax loss for the quarter of $700,000, compared to a pretax income of $2.6 million a year earlier, it said.

Alaska Air said that for the second quarter it posted net income of $20.8 million, or $1.41 per share ($1.01 per share fully diluted), compared with net income of $18.0 million, or $1.24 per share ($0.88 per share fully diluted), for last year's second quarter.
"Continued strong passenger loads and increasing average fares combined to produce an excellent quarter," said Kelly, chairman, president and chief executive officer.

Cost control remains a top priority, he said, adding that the 6 percent increase in Alaska's cost per available seat mile was primarily due to additional staffing to handle large volumes of traffic, improve on-time performance and deal with new security requirements.
